title: 104_s1424
content:
The Act titled "Black Canyon National Park Complex Act of 1996" establishes the Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park. The Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park is established in Colorado, incorporating lands from the abolished Black Canyon National Monument. The Secretary of the Interior will manage the park in accordance with the Act and National Park System laws. The National Park System includes various units established under different Acts of Congress, such as the Act of August 25, 1916 and the Act of August 21, 1935. Establishment of the Gunnison Gorge National Conservation Area. The Gunnison Gorge National Conservation Area in Colorado, covering 64,139 acres, is established and managed by the Secretary through the Bureau of Land Management. Motorized vehicle use is allowed in accordance with existing designations. Within four years of enactment, the Secretary must develop a comprehensive plan for the long-term protection and management of the Gunnison Gorge National Conservation Area in Colorado. The plan will outline appropriate uses and management consistent with the Act, incorporating existing management plans and wildlife habitat management strategies. The Secretary must develop a comprehensive plan for the long-term protection and management of the Gunnison Gorge National Conservation Area in Colorado within four years of enactment. The plan will be prepared in consultation with appropriate agencies of the State of Colorado and use information from previous studies of the area. Establishment of the Curecanti National Recreation Area and the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad National Historic Site. The Curecanti National Recreation Area is established in Colorado, managed by the Secretary through the National Park Service. It is subject to laws applicable to the National Park System. The establishment of the recreation area does not affect existing withdrawals. The Secretary, through the Bureau of Reclamation, is responsible for managing lands with dams and structures under the Colorado River Storage Project Act. A joint agreement will delineate these lands, and additional agreements may address jurisdiction sharing. Lands within the recreation area withdrawn for reclamation purposes will remain subject to established uses. The Secretary administers the recreation area under the Colorado River Storage Project Act, with the ability to exclude areas for reclamation or power purposes. The Denver and Rio Grande National Historic Site is established within the recreation area. The Denver and Rio Grande National Historic Site consists of rolling stock, train trestle at Cimarron, and historic railroad bed within the boundaries of the site. Within the recreation area, the Curecanti Archeological District is established. The Secretary is required to submit a comprehensive list of authorizing documents issued by relevant agencies within one year of the Act's enactment. Bureau of Land Management and the Forest Service use lands in the recreation area, reporting to the Committees on Energy and Natural Resources and Resources of the United States Senate and House of Representatives. SEC. 5. THE ESTABLISHMENT OF THE BLACK CANYON OF THE GUNNISON NATIONAL PARK COMPLEX. The Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park Complex is established in Colorado, including the park, conservation area, recreation area, and portions of the Gunnison National Forest. The Secretary will manage the park, recreation area, historic site, and district, while the Bureau of Land Management will manage the conservation area. The Forest Service will manage the forest portions within the complex. The Secretaries will manage the forest portions within the Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park Complex in accordance with laws and regulations. They will strive to manage areas consistently and share resources to reduce duplication of effort. SEC. 6. WATER RIGHTS.

This Act does not reserve water for any purpose or affect existing water rights, including those held by the United States. The Secretary will acquire necessary water rights following Colorado state laws.

SEC. 7. RECREATIONAL AND MULTIPLE-USE ACTIVITIES. The Secretaries shall provide for general recreation and multiple use activities within their jurisdiction, including swimming, fishing, boating, hiking, camping, and off-road vehicle use. They shall also permit hunting, fishing, and grazing activities. The Secretaries allow hunting, fishing, trapping, and noncommercial taking of fresh-water crustaceans on their lands and waters, following applicable laws. They may designate zones where hunting or trapping is not allowed for safety or public use reasons. Hunting and trapping are not permitted within the park boundaries. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out this Act.
